frontmatter.title: Iterated plus construction produces a sheaf

Given a category \mathcal { C }C\mathcal { C }C equipped with a coverage, we define a presheaf P : \mathcal { C } ^ \textrm {op} \to \mathsf { Set }P:Cop→SetP : \mathcal { C } ^ \textrm {op} \to \mathsf { Set }P:Cop→Set to be a sheaf if it satisfies the sheaf condition: for every cover of AAAA, the map from sections of AAAA to descent data of the cover is a bijection. It is a separated presheaf if the map is an injection.
Sheafification is defined as the left adjoint of the inclusion from sheaves to the category of presheaves. Hence it freely constructs a sheaf from a presheaf.

We construct sheafification as an iterated plus construction. This produces a functor. Hence it is indeed the left adjoint. Alternatively, using , we may compose two adjunctions to first separate the presheaf, and then perform the plus construction. By uniqueness of adjunction these two constructions are equivalent.
